title: Are there any dangerous sharks around the Canary Islands? - Quora

response.answer_text: First, take into account that the waters surrounding the Canary Islands are not particularly warm (temperatures in the first 30 feet are typically between 63 and 77F), which limits the kind of shark that you’re going to find there, and the sharks that you find in tropical waters will avoid them most of the year. Before going on, note that shark attacks are extremely rare in Canary Islands, even by species that are more aggressive in other areas. Whether this is because of the water temperature, because they adapt to the local chill attitude, or some other factor, that’s up to debate. Aside from sand-dwelling species, they tend not to be anywhere close to the beaches, and if they enter one, this is typically by accident, and opt to get away soon… but they’ve been spotted, indeed, and I remember at least one case few years ago when they closed for the day a beach I used to frequent because they had spotted sharks in the bay, that probably had followed a fishing boat back into the port. That said, in the Canaries you may see the following, depending on the season. In boldface, those that may chomp on you: Whale shark (not dangerous)Basking shark (not dangerous)Short fin mako (local name “marrajo”). This is one of the most common in the Canaries, seen all year long. It’s the most likely to attack unprovoked.Atlantic angel shark (aka Sand devil, local name “angelote”). It’s not likely to attack, unless provoked, but it’s been known to bite idiot divers that corner them, leaving some nasty wounds. Their young tend to hide in the sand near the coast, which make them susceptible to be stomped by beachgoers, who may end up with some bite marks around their feet or ankles (but these are quite small, and treatment boils down to applying some antiseptic, nothing of concern)Hammerheads. Seen “relatively” often.White sharks. Yep, they show up relatively often, too.There are more, like the Smalltooth sand tiger (documented only in the last 20 years) but these are the most common. At any rate, and aside the harmless bites from the baby angel sharks, the number of attacks in the last century can be counted with one hand, and you wouldn’t need all your fingers.

Thank you for the A2A. I have lived in Tenerife since 2000 and I have never heard of a single shark attack in that time. Which is not to say there has not been only that if so, the occurrence is rare and underreported. According to this site there have been only 6 unprovoked shark attacks around the Canaries since 1828! Africa (All)

There are Mako and Great Whites in the Atlantic but they feed on fish because there are no marine mammals close to the Canary Islands.
